intro: Scleria georgiana subsp. georgiana, commonly known as the Georgia sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, commonly referred to as the sedge family. The plant typically grows in wetland or marshy habitats, preferring moist, sandy soils. Its leaves are linear and grass-like, with a prominent midrib, and it produces small, clustered spikelets that are characteristic of the sedge family. The plant is often used in ecological restoration projects due to its ability to stabilize soil and support local biodiversity.
